Worked solution

In order to find the integral of the expression \(\textstyle {@expr_6@}\), we need to proceed as follows:

Applying the long division to the expression we obtain,

\(\begin{align*} \displaystyle{@expr_6@} &= {@expr_1@}+{@expr_5@} \\ \displaystyle &= {@expr_1@}+\frac{{@num_expr_5@}}{({@f_5*x+f_3@})({@f_5*x+f_4@})} \end{align*}\)


Next we need to write the proper fraction in its partial fraction decomposition. To do this, we can write it in the required from with unknown constants \(A\) and \(B\):

\(\displaystyle{@expr_5@}\) \(={@num_expr_5@}\displaystyle \left (\frac{A}{{@f_5*x+f_3@}}+\frac{B}{{@f_5*x+f_4@}}\right )\)

Once we solve for the constants \(A\) and \(B\), we can determine the integral. Beforehand we can write the answer in terms of the constants.

\(\begin{align*} \displaystyle \int{@expr_6@}dx &= \int \left ({@expr_1@}\right )dx \hspace{3px} {@if num_expr_5<0 then "-" else "+"@} \hspace{3px} {@abs(num_expr_5)@} \int \left (\frac{A}{{@f_5*x+f_3@}}+\frac{B}{{@f_5*x+f_4@}}\right )dx \\ &= \displaystyle {@expr_7@}+{@num_expr_5@} \left (\frac{A}{{{@f_5@}}} \ln\left |{@f_5*x+f_3@} \right | + \frac{B}{{{@f_5@}}} \ln\left |{@f_5*x+f_4@} \right | \right )+c \end{align*}\)


Now, we proceed by solving,

\(\displaystyle\frac{{@expr_5_1@}}{({@f_5*x+f_3@})({@f_5*x+f_4@})}=\frac{A}{{@f_5*x+f_3@}}+\frac{B}{{@f_5*x+f_4@}} \hspace{20px} \text{equation (i)}\)

Multiplying each member of the equation \(\text{(i)}\) by \({@f_5*x+f_3@},\) we have,

\(\displaystyle \frac{{@expr_5_1@}}{{@f_5*x+f_4@}}=A+B \cdot\left( \frac{{@f_5*x+f_3@}}{{@f_5*x+f_4@}} \right )\) \(\qquad\) equation \((ii)\)

For \(x={@value_x@},\) the equation \(\text{(ii)}\) becomes \(\frac{{@expr_5_1@}}{{@f_5*value_x+f_4@}}=A \implies A={@expr_5_1/(f_5*value_x+f_4)@}\)


Multiplying each member of the equation \(\text{(i)}\) by \({@f_5*x+f_4@}\), we have,

\(\displaystyle \frac{{@expr_5_1@}}{{@f_5*x+f_3@}}=A \cdot\left( \frac{{@f_5*x+f_4@}}{{@f_5*x+f_3@}} \right )+B\)

For \(x={@value_x1@},B={@expr_5_1/(f_5*value_x1+f_3)@}\)


Therefore, the values of \(A={@expr_5_1/(f_5*value_x+f_4)@}\) and \(B={@expr_5_1/(f_5*value_x1+f_3)@}\). Hence,

\(\begin{align*} \displaystyle \int{@expr_6@}dx &= {@expr_7@} + {@num_expr_5/f_5@} \left ({@expr_5_1/(f_5*value_x+f_4)@} \ln\left |{@f_5*x+f_3@} \right | +{@expr_5_1/(f_5*value_x1+f_3)@} \ln\left |{@f_5*x+f_4@} \right | \right )+c \\ \displaystyle &={@expr_7@}+{@(num_expr_5/f_5)/(f_5*value_x+f_4)@} \left (\ln\left |{@f_5*x+f_3@}\right | -\ln\left |{@f_5*x+f_4@} \right | \right ) +c \\ \displaystyle &= {@ta_1@} \end{align*}\)
